comments.body: The design and cool-down mechanic of the Copper Golem is awesome, but its function as a random redstone trigger doesn't mesh with utility for most players. If added it should get a new function one that helps more players, like as an automaton for farming, fishing, or lumber farms. The weather mechanic would ensure players have to engage with it periodically so it's not a simple AFK as it would stop after enough time. Or perhaps give it the ability to collect and move lava from a cauldron to (a chest/barrel), though only if you give it an empty bucket, which could be red-stoned. Making it a useful golem in powering the furnace from lava cauldrons.

please do it i have always wanted camels in the game
The whole point of the Warden is to avoid it though
I agree it's a tough mob to fight but that's because they didn't want people to kill it that is why it doesn't drop much stuff

The warden really isn't designed to be killed, it is more so comparable to a natural disaster such as a tornado or tsunami. You are expected to avoid it, not confront it. The fact that it drops anything at all was surprising to me to be honest.
It's meant to be avoided, so there's not really going to be any useful drops from slaying it, as a means of discouraging doing so. The challenge is tactical avoidance, not battle.
And 1 in 200 have white fur, 1 in 50 in snowy biomes
No real hostile mobs. Maybe they could be neutral, and only attack if attacked, if you approach them too closely, or if you approach their nests.

Like the other comments, they don't want real world hostile mobs. Also, taming them isn't possible irl either, as far as i'm aware. The most you could train them to do is follow you to a spot in reward for a treat to put them in a new habitat location.
I agree, but I don‚Äôt think you should be able to tame them. Feed them yes, but not to tame.
As a fan of cats, I think that would be really cool and more realistic. I wonder if tamed cats would be able to get down though.

My family used to live at a house with a property that had several large ponds, and two families of geese. What you are saying about hostile geese makes total  sense! Whenever we got too close to the geese, they started making hissing noises and acting threatening! I was afraid they were going to attack me! And that was in real life!

Love the idea! But there haven't really been any hostile mobs in the daytime of the overworld yet other than the ocean monsters, and non-fantasy hostile mobs will not be a thing as noted in the list of considered suggestions. Maybe they'll only attack you if you step into their territory (being the dungeons you just mentioned) and so on. I'm not sure how this will work into a game like minecraft but it's definitely a neat idea.
